title: Woman who broke someone's face given chance to turn life around
text:

A woman who battered someone so badly their nose and cheekbone were broken has been given a chance to turn her life around.

Shannon Woodhall subjected her victim to a brutal and sustained attack.

She had accused the woman of offering to perform a sex act on her partner while at a party, a court heard, PlymouthLive reported.

The 21-year-old told the victim: "That's for offering my bloke a **** ***."

Despite the seriousness of the assault, Judge James Townsend decided to give Woodhall a second chance after she admitted causing grievous bodily harm without intent on May 21 last year.

At Plymouth Crown Court he said she was beginning to turn her life around after a difficult childhood and drug habit.

He said: “This was, on any view, a very nasty assault. It was sustained.

(Image: Plymouth Live WS)

“It caused serious injury to your victim and she will continue to be affected well into the future.

"I have been impressed by probation report. You have spent time in prison trying to turn your life around a bit. You had an upbringing most people could not even imagine.

“The most important thing is that you keep on the road to rehabilitation.”

Woodhall was given a two-year prison sentence suspended for two years.

She was also ordered to go on 30 days of intensive probation supervision.

The young woman sobbed constantly through the sentencing hearing before being released from the cells.

Sally Daulton, for the Crown Prosecution Service, said the victim met Woodhall at a party in a flat at Zion House in Devonport – supported accommodation for the homeless run by the Salvation Army.

The two women seemed to get on well and the complainant stayed overnight at a friend’s flat in the block.

The next evening Woodhall burst in with a man called Tommy.

She launched into an attack on the woman, punching and kicking her.

The woman curled up as the blows rained down.

Miss Daulton added: “The defendant told her: ‘If you tell the police, I will finish you off’.”

“Tommy told her: ‘You do not need to slice her up’.”

A friend staying in the flat managed to help Woodhall and Tommy leave.

The woman's orbital bone beneath her eye was broken and cartilage in her nose was fractured.

At first Woodhall denied having met the woman before.

Ali Rafati, defending the woman, said she was known in the courthouse for supporting men on trial.

She had moved out of foster care into independent living where she had become addicted to drugs, the lawyer said.

Mr Rafati added: “Reports from the prison have all been positive.”

He told the court a former employer had offered her a home and would try and find her a job.

Mr Rafati said the man would not tolerate her stepping out of line nor falling back into drugs abuse.
description: Shannon Woodhall was given a second chance by a judge at Plymouth Crown Court
